details.name: Circulating tumor cells (CTCs)
details.description: Cells that have shed into the vasculature or lymphatics from a primary tumor and circulate in the bloodstream.
details.findings: CTCs can be isolated to study DNA methylation patterns indicative of cancer progression.
details.notes: Used for studying DNA methylation and identifying potential therapeutic targets.

details.name: DNA methylation
details.description: An epigenetic mechanism that involves the addition of a methyl group to DNA, affecting gene expression.
details.findings: Distinctive DNA methylation patterns in CTCs are associated with cancer progression and can be used as biomarkers.
details.notes: Utilized for identifying potential therapeutic targets in colorectal cancer.

knowledge.subject: DNA methylation
knowledge.object: addition of a methyl group to DNA

details.name: Methylation sites
details.description: Specific locations on the DNA where a methyl group is added, affecting gene expression.
details.findings: Differential methylation of these sites in CTCs can serve as biomarkers for colorectal cancer progression.
details.notes: Used to distinguish between different stages and subtypes of colorectal cancer.

knowledge.subject: Methylation sites
knowledge.predicate: are specific locations on DNA affected by

details.name: Acute phase proteins
details.description: Proteins whose plasma concentrations increase (positive acute phase proteins) or decrease (negative acute phase proteins) in response to inflammation.
details.findings: Their concentration changes can be used as a diagnostic marker for inflammatory diseases.
details.notes: Acute phase proteins include CRP, serum amyloid A protein, fibrinogen, and more.

knowledge.subject: Acute phase proteins
knowledge.object: proteins whose plasma concentrations change in response to inflammation

details.name: C-reactive protein (CRP)
details.description: A positive acute phase protein used as a diagnostic marker for inflammatory diseases.
details.findings: CRP levels are measured by clinical laboratories to indicate inflammation and infection.
details.notes: CRP is part of the innate immune system.

details.name: Serum amyloid A protein
details.description: A positive acute phase protein involved in the inflammatory response.
details.findings: It serves as a diagnostic marker for inflammation, similar to CRP.
details.notes: Its levels increase during inflammation.

details.name: Fibrinogen
details.description: A glycoprotein that plays a role in blood clotting and is also an acute phase protein.
details.findings: Fibrinogen levels rise during inflammatory responses, aiding in diagnosis.
details.notes: It is part of the positive acute phase proteins.

knowledge.subject: Fibrinogen
knowledge.object: a glycoprotein and an acute phase protein

details.name: Protein C
details.description: A vitamin K-dependent protein involved in the regulation of blood coagulation and inflammation.
details.findings: Its concentration changes during inflammatory conditions, providing diagnostic insights.
details.notes: It is one of the acute phase proteins measured for inflammation.

knowledge.subject: Protein C
knowledge.object: the regulation of blood coagulation and inflammation

details.name: Lipoprotein (a)
details.description: A low-density lipoprotein variant associated with increased risk of cardiovascular diseases.
details.findings: Levels can indicate inflammation and are used in diagnostics for related conditions.
details.notes: It is considered an acute phase protein.

details.name: Alpha-1-antitrypsin
details.description: A protease inhibitor that protects tissues from enzymes of inflammatory cells.
details.findings: Its levels are indicative of inflammation and used in diagnostic tests.
details.notes: It is another acute phase protein involved in the immune response.

details.name: Haptoglobin
details.description: A protein that binds free hemoglobin released from erythrocytes, playing a role in inflammation.
details.findings: Its concentration increases during inflammatory responses, aiding diagnosis.
details.notes: It is part of the positive acute phase proteins.

details.name: Alpha-1-acid glycoprotein
details.description: A serum protein with immunomodulatory and anti-inflammatory properties.
details.findings: Its levels rise during inflammation, providing diagnostic information.
details.notes: It is an acute phase reactant measured in inflammatory conditions.

details.name: Ferritin
details.description: A protein that stores iron and releases it in a controlled fashion, involved in inflammation.
details.findings: Its levels increase during inflammation, serving as a diagnostic marker.
details.notes: It is part of the acute phase proteins.

details.name: Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL)
details.description: A protein associated with kidney injury and inflammation.
details.findings: Its levels are measured to assess inflammatory conditions and renal function.
details.notes: It is an acute phase reactant used in diagnostics.

details.name: miR-126
details.description: A microRNA included in the CEx-miRNAs panel for early CRC diagnosis and prognosis.
details.findings: miR-126 has shown promising predictive data for early CRC stages as part of a biomarker panel.
details.notes: Part of a CEx-miRNAs panel used for minimally invasive detection methods like blood samples (serum).

details.name: miR-1290
details.description: A microRNA included in the CEx-miRNAs panel for early CRC diagnosis and prognosis.
details.findings: miR-1290 has shown promising predictive data for early CRC stages as part of a biomarker panel.
details.notes: Part of a CEx-miRNAs panel used for minimally invasive detection methods like blood samples (serum).

details.name: miR-23a
details.description: A microRNA included in the CEx-miRNAs panel for early CRC diagnosis and prognosis.
details.findings: miR-23a has shown promising predictive data for early CRC stages as part of a biomarker panel.
details.notes: Part of a CEx-miRNAs panel used for minimally invasive detection methods like blood samples (serum).

details.name: miR-940
details.description: A microRNA included in the CEx-miRNAs panel for early CRC diagnosis and prognosis.
details.findings: miR-940 has shown promising predictive data for early CRC stages as part of a biomarker panel.
details.notes: Part of a CEx-miRNAs panel used for minimally invasive detection methods like blood samples (serum).

details.name: MSI-H
details.description: Microsatellite instability-high status in colorectal cancer.
details.findings: Confers substantial improvements in clinical outcomes and decreased toxicities through immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI).
details.notes: Predictive of the response to ICI, offering patients long-term survival or near curative results.

knowledge.subject: MSI-H
knowledge.object: substantial improvements in clinical outcomes and decreased toxicities

details.name: RAS
details.description: A family of genes involved in cellular signal transduction.
details.findings: Has necessitated a molecular-targeted approach in colorectal cancer (CRC).
details.notes: Part of the predictive biomarker landscape for targeted therapies in CRC.

details.name: BRAF V600E
details.description: A specific mutation in the BRAF gene, associated with poor prognosis.
details.findings: Predictive of response to combined targeted BRAF/EGFR inhibition, doubling survival over standard treatments.
details.notes: Previously had a negative prognostic value but now serves as a predictive biomarker for certain therapies.

knowledge.subject: BRAF V600E
knowledge.object: response to combined targeted BRAF/EGFR inhibition

details.name: KRAS
details.description: A gene involved in cellular signal transduction pathways.
details.findings: Reprograms cellular metabolism, making KRAS-mutant tumors more susceptible to ferroptosis induction as a potential clinical strategy.
details.notes: Influence on glutamine metabolism and susceptibility to targeted therapies like ferroptosis induction.

details.name: Ferroptosis
details.description: A form of regulated cell death distinct from apoptosis and necrosis.
details.findings: Explored in combination therapy with immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) as a promising strategy to increase sensitivity and overcome resistance.
details.notes: Related to glutamine metabolism, particularly through the synthesis of glutathione (GSH) and glutaminolysis.

knowledge.subject: Ferroptosis
knowledge.predicate: is explored in combination therapy with

details.name: Glutamine Metabolism
details.description: A metabolic process involving the synthesis of glutathione (GSH) and through glutaminolysis.
details.findings: Regulates ferroptosis, contributing to the susceptibility of KRAS-mutant tumors to therapeutic strategies.
details.notes: Key in the context of ferroptosis and its potential use in cancer treatment strategies.

details.name: Gefitinib
details.description: An epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat certain cancers.
details.findings: Gefitinib was tested for its ability to prevent proliferation of cancer cells in a 3D tumor model.
details.notes: The study explored the effect of Gefitinib on EGFR mutant lung adenocarcinoma cells.

knowledge.subject: Gefitinib
knowledge.predicate: tested for its ability to prevent proliferation
knowledge.object: cancer cells in a 3D tumor model

details.name: EGFR mutant lung adenocarcinoma cells
details.description: Cells with mutations in the epidermal growth factor receptor involved in lung adenocarcinoma.
details.findings: These cells were shown to be less responsive to Gefitinib when grown as multicellular aggregates compared to monolayers.
details.notes: This finding highlights the complexity of drug response in different cellular environments.

knowledge.subject: EGFR mutant lung adenocarcinoma cells
knowledge.predicate: were shown to be less responsive to
knowledge.object: Gefitinib when grown as multicellular aggregates

details.name: 3D tumor model
details.description: A model that mimics the three-dimensional structure of a tumor for research purposes.
details.findings: The 3D tumor model was used to evaluate the efficacy of Gefitinib on cancer cells.
details.notes: This model provides a more realistic environment compared to traditional two-dimensional cell cultures.

knowledge.subject: 3D tumor model
knowledge.object: the efficacy of Gefitinib on cancer cells

details.name: Cellular aggregates (multicellular spheroids)
details.description: Clusters of cells that form three-dimensional structures used in biological research.
details.findings: Cells grown as multicellular aggregates exhibited different responses to Gefitinib than when grown in monolayers.
details.notes: This indicates the importance of cellular architecture in drug response studies.

knowledge.subject: Cellular aggregates (multicellular spheroids)
knowledge.object: Gefitinib than when grown in monolayers

details.name: Monolayer cultures
details.description: A method of growing cells in a single layer, commonly used in biological research.
details.findings: Cells grown in monolayers responded differently to Gefitinib compared to those in multicellular aggregates.
details.notes: The difference highlights the limitations of traditional 2D cultures in mimicking tumor environments.

knowledge.subject: Monolayer cultures

details.name: Drug resistance
details.description: The reduction in effectiveness of a drug such as an antimicrobial or an antineoplastic in curing a disease.
details.findings: Multicellular aggregates demonstrated increased resistance to Gefitinib compared to monolayer cultures.
details.notes: Understanding the mechanisms behind this resistance is crucial for improving cancer treatment strategies.

details.name: Guanylate cyclase-C (GCC)
details.description: A protein targeted by chimeric antigen receptor in the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer.
details.findings: Chimeric antigen receptors targeting GCC showed efficacy and safety, resulting in partial responses in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer.
details.notes: Immunohistochemistry data for GCC was performed and interpreted as part of the study.

knowledge.subject: Chimeric antigen receptor targeting Guanylate cyclase-C

details.name: hCRISPRs
details.description: Human CRISPR-like sequences involved in transcription regulation and diagnostics.
details.findings: The study aimed to detect and validate hCRISPRs for their roles in transcription and diagnostics.
details.notes: hCRISPRs are part of the research into CRISPR-Cas-related patents.

details.name: acetone
details.description: A compound with an abnormal fruity odor in breath.
details.findings: Acetone concentration changes during activities such as exercising or fasting, limiting its use as a cancer biomarker.
details.notes: Its variability due to external factors affects its reliability for cancer detection.

details.name: 4-heptanone
details.description: A compound with unclear origins.
details.findings: Not recommended for use as biomarkers due to unclear origins and limited research.
details.notes: Its application is constrained by the lack of understanding of its production sources in the body.

knowledge.subject: 4-heptanone
knowledge.predicate: is not recommended for use as

details.name: VOCs (general)
details.description: Compounds in exhaled breath containing valuable information about cancer metabolism.
details.findings: Analyzing VOCs can reduce the need for invasive tests and assist early cancer detection.
details.notes: Advanced instruments like SIFT-MS, combined with machine learning, enhance the prediction accuracy of cancer using VOCs.

details.name: microbiome biomarkers
details.description: Specific markers within the microbiome that can differentiate between healthy and diseased states, particularly in colorectal cancer.
details.findings: The study identified specific microbiome biomarkers using XAI methods to aid in distinguishing colorectal cancer.
details.notes: Biomarkers were analyzed with publicly available datasets from Zenodo repository and GitHub.

details.name: VOCs
details.description: Volatilomic markers identified in exhaled breath using sensor technology for CRC detection.
details.findings: Sensor technology with VOC detection shows comparable or better accuracy than the FIT test for CRC and precancerous lesion detection.
details.notes: The study found specific VOCs such as alkenes, alcohols, ketones, and esters in CRC patients' breath.

knowledge.subject: sensor technology
knowledge.object: CRC patients and controls with high accuracy

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A secondary product of lipid peroxidation, associated with ketosis.
details.findings: Elevated in CRC patients' breath due to high oxidation rates of fatty acids.
details.notes: Related to the metabolism and oxidative stress processes.

knowledge.subject: Acetone
knowledge.predicate: forms under metabolic conditions associated with
knowledge.object: high oxidation rate of fatty acids

details.name: Alcohols
details.description: Derive from food, alcohol beverages, and metabolism by cytochrome p450 enzymes.
details.findings: Presence in breath due to food intake and metabolic processes.
details.notes: Contribute to the VOC profile in exhaled breath.

knowledge.subject: Alcohols
knowledge.predicate: are derived from metabolism of hydrocarbons by

details.name: Esters
details.description: Compounds found in natural sources such as fats, oils, waxes, and fruits.
details.findings: Detected in CRC patients' breath contributing to VOC profile.
details.notes: Part of the diverse range of compounds identified through sensor technology.

knowledge.subject: Esters
knowledge.predicate: can be found in large amounts in
knowledge.object: natural sources such as fats and fatty oils, waxes, and fruit ethers

details.name: T-antigen
details.description: A cancer-associated glycan marker indicative of abnormal immature glycan signatures in aggressive lesions.
details.findings: Stools from more aggressive lesions exhibit abnormal immature T-antigen glycan signatures not seen in healthy tissues.
details.notes: Potential for non-invasive cancer diagnostics; exploratory nature limits robustness.

details.name: Stool Glycoproteome
details.description: Characterization of molecular targets in stool that are shared by aggressive non-cancerous lesions and cancer.
details.findings: Identifies several molecular targets shared by more aggressive non-cancerous lesions and cancer, which hold promise for future pre-clinical assessment.
details.notes: Provides a framework for addressing glycosylation alterations; requires screening larger patient cohorts.

phi4:14b/PPEkf.prompt_template:
[BEGIN ARTICLE]:<content></content>
[END ARTICLE]

[INSTRUCTIONS]
Generate list of biomarkers that are topic of the article and for each such biomarker extract name, description, type, findings explicitly mentioned in the article, and list of knowledge.
The list of knowledge that are from finding and that can be expressed in terms: 'subject' which is the biomarker, 'predicate' which is some verb optionally with some adverb and 'object'.
Return the response in strict JSON format with the following structure:

[
  { "name": "biomarker name","type":"biomarker type","description":"biomarker description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker", "knowledge":[{'subject':'repeated biomarker name','predicate':'some predicate from findings of biomarker','object':'object that relates via predicate to the biomarker' }],
  { "name": "biomarker2 name","type":"biomarker2 type","description":"biomarker2 description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker2 in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker2", "knowledge":[{'subject':'repeated biomarker2 name','predicate':'some predicate from findings of  biomarker2','object':'object that relates via predicate to the biomarker2' }] }
] 

Ensure there is no additional explanation, only return valid JSON.
